title: Gaius: Praetor 44 B.C. Brother of Mark Antony. Commanded forces against the republicans in Illyricum where he was defeated and killed. Antonius, lullus: Antony and Fulvia's younger son

note: Led the war against the republicans at Perusia.
title: Tribune 44 B.C., consul 41 B.C. Brother of Mark Antony

note: Antonius "Antyllus," Marcus: Antony and Fulvia's elder son. Killed in Egypt.
title: Consul 99 B.C., censor 97 B.C. Fought pirates in Cilicia. Leading orator

container-title: Artavasdes: King of Media Atropatene, hostile to Artavasdes of Armenia
note: Antonius Creticus, Marcus: Praetor 74
publisher: King of Armenia, son of Artavasdes
title: Held command in Crete against the pirates

Favored Catiline. Arsinoe: Sister of Cleopatra. Opposed Cleopatra and was killed by Antony. Artavasdes: King of Armenia. Betrayed Antony in campaign against Parthia, 36 B.C. Antony invaded Armenia and took him captive to Egypt in 34 B.C
Titus Pomponius: Financier and man of learning who was the diplomatic friend of all important men, especially of Cicero
Lucius Cornelius: Quaestor 44 B.C., consul 40 B.C
Lucius Calpurnius: Grandson of Cato. Served Antony as governor of Syria, 32 B.C. Bocchus: King of Mauretania who supported current winners in the civil war

note: Died at Philippi.
title: Praetor 44 B.C. A Pompeian, he was pardoned by Caesar after Pharsalus and made governor of Cisalpine Gaul. Assassinated Caesar and became the moral leader of the republicans and a general in the east
Decimus Junius: Praetor 45 B.C. Caesar's aide who was one of his assassins. Besieged by Antony at Mutina and executed by Antony's order

note: Murdered in 44 B.C. Caesarion: Son of Cleopatra and supposed son of Caesar. Killed by Octavian in 30 B.C.
title: Gaius Julius: Consul 59 B.C., proconsul in Gaul and Illyricum 58-49 B.C., dictator 49-48 and 47-44 B.C. Antony's commander in Gaul and in the civil war
Quintus Fufius: Consul 47 B.C., Antony's governor of Gaul 43-40 B.C. Calpurnia: Wife of Caesar, daughter of Lucius Calpurnius Piso. Collaborated with Antony after Caesar's death

note: Died patrolling the Adriatic Sea.
title: Marcus: Consul 59 B.C. with Caesar. Supported Pompey against Caesar in the civil war

container-title: Father-in-law of Caesar. Political moderator between Pompey and Caesar
title: Lucius: Consul 58 B.C., censor 50 B.C
Publius: Consul 40 B.C. Antony's loyal commander in the east and at Actium
Gaius Fonteius: Consul 33 B.C. Antony's ambassador to Rome

note: Died at Philippi.
title: Gaius: Praetor 44 B.C. Opposed Caesar and was pardoned by him. Assassin of Caesar. General in the east for the republicans
Quintus: With Antony, tribune for Caesar in 49 B.C. Legate in Spain for Caesar during the civil war
Led a revolution against the state (in 63 B.C.) which was crushed by Cicero

note: Died a republican martyr at Utica.
title: Marcus Porcius: Praetor 54 B.C. Conservative leader of the republicans. Fought the Second Triumvirate
Marcus Tullius: Consul 63 B.C. Rome's greatest orator. Republican supporter of Pompey. Later favored Octavian and denounced Antony in the Philippic Orations

author.literal: Cicero, Quintus Tullius: Nephew of Cicero theorator.

publisher: Daughter of Fulvia, stepdaughter of Antony
title: Fought with Caesar, then Antony, then the republicans. Executed by the Second Triumvirate
Queen of Egypt, fifth wife of Antony

container-title: Killed by Milo in a brawl. Commius: Gallic chieftain of the Atrebates
note: Defeated by Antony. Cotiso: King of the Getae. Supporter of Antony.
title: Publius: Tribune 58 B.C., consul 54 B.C. Married to Fulvia. Popular leader who was bitter toward Cicero, sometimes friendly to Antony, sometimes hostile. Leader of street gangs

note: Agent for Caesar. Died fighting for Caesar in Africa. Cytheris: Roman actress, mistress of Antony.
title: Marcus Licinius: Consul 70 and 55 B.C., censor 65 B.C. Member of the First Triumvirate. Died fighting the Parthians at Carrhae in 53 B.C. Curio, Gaius Scribonius: Tribune 50 B.C. Boyhood friend of Antony
Lucius: Tribune 44 B.C. Antony's governor of Syria, killed fighting the Parthians. Deiotarus:King of Galatia

note: Deserted at Actium.
title: Historian friend and diplomatic agent of Antony in the east
Publius Cornelius: Consul with Antony in 44 B.C. Cicero's sonin-law. Supporter of Caesar and leader of the Caesarians in the east, where he was killed
Ruler of Sparta who attacked Antony after Actium. Fadia: Antony's first wife

note: Gabinius died fighting for Caesar in the civil war. Glaphyra: Antony's mistress, to whose son he gave the throne of Cappadocia.
title: Gaius: Praetor 42 B.C., Antony's governor of Asia 36 B.C. Gabinius, Aulus: Consul 58 B.C., proconsul in Syria 57-54 B.C. Antony served under him in Syria and in illegally restoring Ptolemy XII to the throne of Egypt
Herod the Great: King of Judaea who received his throne from Antony and fought for him

note: Died fighting the Antonians at Mutina.
title: Aulus: Consul 43 B.C. Close supporter of Caesar; he completed Caesar's Commentaries
Quintus (Horace): Republican soldier who fought under Brutus
Hortensius Hortalus, Quintus: Praetor 45 B.C., governor of Macedonia 44 B.C. Republican executed by Antony after Philippi

note: lotape: Daughter of Artavasdes of Media, betrothed to Alexander Helios.
title: High priest of the Jews under Pompey and Gabinius, ethnarch under Caesar
King of Numidia and Mauretania, married to Antony and Cleopatra's daughter

container-title: Lentulus Sura, Publius Cornelius: Consul 71 B.C. Antony's stepfather. Leader in Catilinarian conspiracy of 63 B.C
note: Executed by Cicero.
title: Republican son of the Pompeian Titus Labienus. Fled to Parthia for sanctuary and led a Parthian army against Syria in 40 B.C

Marcus Aemilius: Patrician magister equitum under Caesar 46-44 B.C., consul 46 B.C., pontifex maximus for life. Member of the Second Triumvirate. Defeated in Sicily by Octavian and deposed from the triumvirate

note: Hostile to Herod the Great and Cleopatra, although he sent troops to Antony.
title: Lucius Licinius: Consul 74 B.C. Commander against Mithridates. Arranged the affairs of many states of Asia Minor while proconsul in Bithynia and Pontus, 73-67 B.C. Maecenas, Gaius: Close friend and diplomatic agent for Octavian. Malchus: King of the Nabataeans
Gaius Claudius: Octavia's first husband, supporter of Pompey. Mariamne: Wife of Herod the Great
Marcus Valerius: Consul 31 B.C. A republican who became loyal to Octavian
Quintus Caecilius: Consul 52 B.C. Pompeian supporter who died fighting the Caesarians in Africa

note: Convicted for Clodius's murder despite Cicero's attempts to defend him.
title: Titus Annius: Tribune 57 B.C., praetor 55 B.C. A street brawler whom Pompey used to oppose Clodius's gangs
King of Pontus who waged repeated wars against Rome, 88-68 B.C. Monaeses: Parthian noble who defected for a time to Antony and encouraged his Parthian campaign

container-title: Biographer of Augustus. Octavia: Grandniece of Caesar, sister of Octavian, fourth wife of Antony
title: Nicolaus of Damascus: Tutor for Antony's children in Alexandria. Court historian for Herod the Great
Gaius Julius Caesar (Octavian): Grandnephew and heir of Caesar. Member of the Second Triumvirate. Victor over Antony at Actium and Alexandria

publisher: Prince of Parthia. Invaded Roman-held Syria
title: King of Parthia whose troops defeated Crassus and took many of Rome's eastern lands

note: Supporter of Caesar. Died fighting the Antonians at Mutina.
title: Gaius Vibius: Consul 43 B.C
Quintus: Consul 43 B.C. Caesar's grandnephew and minor heir

note: Supported Antony. Married Antony's granddaughter.
title: Lucius Munatius: Consul 42 B.C. Military leader, shifting sides to his own advantage during the civil war, but generally aiding Antony
Gaius Asinius: Consul 40 B.C. Supported Caesar, then Antony. In 38 B.C. he left political-military life to become a historian, poet, and patron of Vergil and Horace
Gnaeus: Elder son of Pompey the Great. Led the Pompeians fighting in Spain

Sextus: Younger son of Pompey the Great. Seized Sicily and other lands of the western Mediterranean after Pharsalus, and his camp became a center for anti-Caesarians. Defeated by Octavian and died by order of Antony

container-title: Broke with Caesar in 49 B.C. and was vanquished at Pharsalus in 48 B.C. Died in Egypt
publisher: Daughter of Cato, wife of Marcus Brutus
title: Gnaeus: Consul 70, 55, 52 B.C. Member of the First Triumvirate
King of Egypt restored to his throne by Gabinius and Antony, Father of Cleopatra

note: Married Antony's eldest daughter, Antonia.
title: Joint ruler of Egypt with his sister Cleopatra. Died fighting Caesar in 47 B.C. Ptolemy XIII: Joint ruler of Egypt with his sister Cleopatra. Murdered by Cleopatra in 44 B.C. Ptolemy Philadelphus: Younger son of Antony and Cleopatra
Gaius: Extortionate financial agent for Ptolemy XII in Egypt

container-title: Lieutenant of Caesar. Governor of Numidia 46-45 B.C. Retired from political life to write history
title: Gaius (Sallust): Tribune 52 B.C

container-title: Executed by Octavian. Scribonia: Second wife of Octavian, Sextus Pompey's aunt
title: Quintus: Consul designate 39 B.C. Octavian'slongtime friend and military officer. Defected to Antony in 40 B.C

note: Strong political influence in republican councils.
title: Lucius: Consul 34 B.C. Father-in-law of Sextus Pompey. Hostile to Caesar. Agent between Sextus and Antony
Publius: Consul 48 and 41 B.C. Supporter of Caesar, then of Octavian and Antony. A trimmer
Gaius: Consul 32 B.C. Antony's agent in Greece

container-title: Defected to Octavian in 32 B.C. Titius, Publius: Tribune 43 B.C. Proposed the Lex Titia which established the Second Triumvirate
title: Consul 31 B.C. Antony's lieutenant against the Parthians and Sextus Pompey
Tribune 47 B.C. Lieutenant for Antony at Mutina
Gaius: Consul 45 B.C. Officer under Caesar in GauJ. Then republican supporter who spoke of Caesar's murder to Antony and detained Antony outside the Curia Pompeii on the Ides of March
Marcus Terentius: Praetor before 67 B.C. Librarian and historian. A Pompeian, forgiven by Caesar, proscribed but not killed by the Second Triumvirate
Publius: Consul 47 B.C. Useful agent for Caesar and the Second Triumvirate

Publius: Consul 43 B.C. Antony's general who fought in Perusia and against the Parthians. Vercingetorix: Chief of the Arverni tribe. Led a revolt of the Gauls against Rome. Besieged and defeated by Caesar and Antony at Alesia
